Definitely! The Gaddi festival features several traditional dances performed by the locals, which are an integral part of the celebrations. Here are some of the dances you might see during the festival:

1. Kinnauri Nati – This dance is performed primarily by women, who wear traditional Kinnauri dresses and jewellery. The dance involves moving in a circular motion while holding hands, and the steps are accompanied by singing and clapping.

2. Kharait – This dance is performed by men dressed in long robes and turbans. The dance features slow and quick movements and celebrates the harvesting season.

3. Dandaras – This dance is performed with wooden sticks, and the dancers move in and out of a circle as they strike the sticks together. The dance is known for its fast-paced rhythm and loud, energetic music.

4. Chohara – This is a dance performed by men who dress up in colorful clothes and move in a circular motion. They carry sticks and gradually build up a tempo as they perform the dance.

5. Bnagi-Bnagi – This is a playful dance performed by young boys and girls in a circle formation. They hold hands while twirling and singing songs.

These are just a few of the many dances that you might see during the Gaddi festival. Each dance has its unique style, music, and significance. They all offer a glimpse into the rich cultural heritage and traditions of the region.
